TextView.android:text: Freedom is hammered out on the anvil of discussion, dissent and refute. To oppugn or opine, that is the question. The annual debate is a platform to exhibit how well you can prove what you say. Every year, it becomes a crowning jewel of Techtrix, standing witness to the sharpest minds of the generation battle it out on stage, stating, refusing, agreeing or denying the motion set forth. Be a part of VERBOSE 2K17 and put your hours of practice to good use with the witty tongues!

* The debate format is parliamentary.
 * Anyone under the age of 25 is allowed to participate.
 * School students, cross-college and cross-school teams are allowed to participate.
 * Each and every student must bring their ID-Cards which is mandatory.
 * A nominal registration fee of Rs. 60/- is required for each team to participate.
 * The motion for the debate will be decided based on a lottery 1 hour before the event begins.
 * Each participating team must consist of two members. One speaking 'for' and the other speaking 'against' the motion.
 * Each speaker will be allotted 4+1=5 minutes to put across his speech.
 * A reminder bell will be used at the fourth minute.
 * A question round will follow right after the completion of every speech. Two questions shall be allowed (One from the judge and one from the audience).
 * Exceeding the time limit will reflect upon scores.
 * The order of teams to debate shall be decided based on a lottery in the beginning.
 * Only Parliamentary language will be entertained. (no abusive language)
 * Obscenity and vulgarity in any form won’t be tolerated.
 * No props allowed on stage. Reading out from written materials will reflect upon scores.
 * Rules are subject to modification based on circumstances.

These are the criteria on which the debate will be judged and scored:

* Factual accuracy. 
* Arguments (not assertions) : You can’t convince anyone that gay marriage undermines traditional marriage just by saying so. You have to lead the judge through the reasoning, showing causal connections. 
* Impact : You must tell the judge why your arguments matter. 
* Reasonableness : Don’t offer straw men or draw warrantless exaggerations. 
* Addressing your team member’s points. 
* Adhering to the time limit. 
* Confidence and overall presentation.

A 10 point scale will be used to assign the scores with fractional values allowed. The scale will look like this: 
0--Blatantly offensive, person didn’t get up to speak, spit on you, etc. (MUST BE JUSTIFIED)

1-2--Extremely poor--barely coherent. An extreme statement.

3--Not too good--maybe a couple of good points, but generally unfocused and ineffective.

4-5-–Low average and high average respectively--no major highs, but no major mistakes either. Generally solid.

6--Very good--compelling, intelligent, no noticeable mistakes. A person who averages this score should be in the top ten speakers at the event.

7--Exceptional--one of the best speeches you expect to be given at the event. A person who averages this should be in contention for a spot as one of the top three speakers at the event.

8--Phenomenal--moved you to tears. The best speech you ever expected to hear ever. (MUST BE JUSTIFIED)

9--Martin Luther King on a good day. A very rare case.

10--Christ, Moses, and M.L.K. rolled up into one, on steroids. No chance. Never seen this. (Actually, one of these existed once--began with “Let there be light.” Perhaps you’ve heard of it?) Forget about even thinking about believing you can get this.
Note : Rules are Subject to Change if Circumstances Demands
